Executive Summary



This Executive summary is prepared in conformance with the provisions of 40 CFR 68.155.



1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source



The facility adheres to the federal, state, and local rules and regulations. The facility is in compliance with the OSHA requirements for handling of anhydrous ammonia and the OSHA process management standard. Employees of the facilities are engaged in ongoing training about their responsibilities in implementing compliance programs. Should an emergency occur, it the company's policy to notify the Detroit Fire department and request that they respond to the emergency situation 



2. Stationary source and regulated substances handled



Anhydrous ammonia is stored in a bulk tank at the facility. The facility is engaged in heat treatment of steel. Heat treatment process involves introducing ammonia in the controlled ovens containing metal. 



3. The worst case release scenario and the alternative release scenario including the administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for the reported scenarios



The worst-case scenario for the facility is considered to be the release of the contents of the tank when filled to the maximum allowed limit under written administrative controls (11900 gallons of ammonia; 59500 pounds of ammonia). The distance corresponding to 59500 lbs of ammonia release is 2.83 miles.



The alternative release scenario identified for the facility is the release through the transfer line connecting the tank with the transfer hose of anhydrous ammonia delivery truck that loads the tank. In this scenario, the liquid contained in the transfer line empties out, and the check valve closes, limiting the loss to the contents of the line (approximately 75 lbs). The attendant will then close the main loading valve at the tank. The maximum distance corresponding to the release of 75 pounds is 0.1 miles.



4. The general accidental

release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps



The facility is in compliance with the USEPA's accidental release prevention rule and with the applicable state and local codes and regulations. The design, installation and maintenance of anhydrous ammonia tank is performed in conformance with ANSI standards, state and local regulations. Facility personnel have been trained in accordance with safe handling procedures developed by Tanner Industries, the supplier of both tank and anhydrous ammonia to the facility.

 

The material handling activity is performed after all of the following precautions are met:

* The truck has backed up to the transfer loading pipe

* The transfer hose has been attached by the delivery truck operators

* Inspection by both the truck and facility operators has occurred

* The load has been accepted by the facility



All the transfer operations are monitored and follow a written standard operating procedure (SOP)



5. The five-year accident history



The facility has not had any accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, and evacuations or sheltering in place.



6. The emergency response program



In the event of an emergency, it is the policy of the facility to notify the Detroit Fire Department and request for their response. This policy has been discussed with the fire department. The Fire Marshall has inspected the tank at the facility.



7. Planned changes to improve safety



The employees are trained on a regular basis. If any change occurs in the federal, state, and local regulations, the safety training is updated as per the revisions. The plant systems are upgraded continuously for safety as new equipment is installed.
